Half-Life 2: Episode One 1 was released a bit over 8 years ago, as the even then long-awaited expansion of the original, critically widely acclaimed game. Since it is part of the Orange Box, the Half-Life 2 Complete Edition and the Valve Complete Edition, chances are great you already own and have played the original Half-Life 2.The good news: Episode 1 continues on the high level of level design and gameplay the original had set. There is however an important shift in focus, as the greater part of the game is played alongside Alyx, Gordon's female companion-in-arms. Alyx happily stands her own against the enemy hordes and doesn't need any sort of "babysitting" games wtih less well developed AI sometimes call for. She's been updated graphically as well (looking even better ;-)) since Episode 1 makes use of the High Dynamic Range lighting effects first tried out by Valve in Half-Life 2: Lost Coast. However, compared to that playable tech-demo, environments in Episode 1 are a bit disappointing and don't always offer the best opportunities for the upgraded engine to shine. There are no wide-open vistas, and although the opening level in the Citadel is impressive, it also has a sort of repetitiveness that comes to the fore now and then.On the other hand, gameplay-wise everything is as top-notch as it was in the original game, and the fact that you play alongside Alyx offers some interesting opportunities. There's even a Steam Achievement called "One Bullet" which gets unlocked by playing through the entire game (!!) using one single bullet. The rest of the kills/actions has to be made by using the Gravity Gun, which gets an upgrade during the early part of the game. This calls for clever thinking, and I tried to get it, only to find myself missing the shooting action after a couple of hours ;-).All in all, Episode 1 is a good to very good expansion, continuing the story of the original game in a logical and interesting way. There's no reason at all not to give it a shot (...) when you've played the original Half-Life 2.Overall rating: 8/10

-Quick Review-Half-Life 2: Episode One was Developed by Valve Corporation and released 2006. Not much changed from Half-Life 2, this game is a continuation and starts right after the events of Half-Life 2.


Half-Life 2 - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2: Episode One
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Story: After the events that took place in Half-Life 2, Gordon and Alyx Vance are reunited and need to escape City 17. Unfortunately, they cannot escape before the Citadel's core detonates. So Alex and Gordon are forced to enter the Citadel to stabilize the core long enough for them to safely escape.


Story Sample - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2: Episode One
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: There are only two changes to the core game: First, Alex's AI has been dramatically improved, so she is more helpful and not nearly as annoying as most NPC's that simply repeat the same phrases and actions. Second, you start the game with the Gravity Gun, which is utilized both in combat and puzzle solutions.


Combat - Uploaded for the review 
A Screenshot of Half-Life 2: Episode One
By: Atratzu




Achievements: There are 13 achievements in Half-Life 2: Episode One. Five achievements are unlocked by just completing the game, the rest are achieved by special circumstances. (like... “beating the game firing exactly one bullet”, “not killing any stalkers”, or “killing an elite soldier with his own energy ball”)To be honest, these achievements aren't very bad, this was a relatively easy 100% completed game, compared to others games.Price: Half-Life 2: Episode One, is priced at $7.99, unfortunately the game is very short, and this price is a bit high for the amount of time it will take to play through the game. (You will probably spend about 5 or 6 hours to beat it)A far better alternative, is to purchase The Orange Box for $19.99, you will purchase: Half-Life 2, Half-Life 2: Episode one, Half Life 2: Episode Two, and Portal.Conclusion: Story: Still very good, but unfortunately much shorter then Half-Life 2. Gameplay: Pretty much the same as Half-Life 2, the only difference is you use the Gravity gun much more, and much sooner. Achievements: Straightforward, fairly obtainable 100% completed game. Price: Over priced, wait for a sale, or purchase the Orange Box for the best value.I recommend this game to anyone who played Half-Life 2 and wants to continue the story of the Freeman...Related reviewsHere's the URL to see my review for  Half-Life 2Here's the URL to see my review for  Half-Life 2: Episode TwoHere's the URL to see my review for Half-Life 3 ...(...is what I would say if it was released yet *sob*)

												Half-Life 2: Episode One begine right where Half-Life 2 ended, and continues the story of Dr.Gordon Freeman in City 17, however, this time, the priority remains to escape the city following the events of Half-Life 2.With updated lighting and AI for deuteragonist Alyx Vance, and expanded usage for the Gravity Gun, Half-Life 2: Episode One continues Half-Life 2's usage of advanced graphics, physics, music and writing to create a game that is both rich in gameplay, plot, and emotion. Like its predecessor, it uses training techniques to allow for a more fluid experience, and utilizes the game's physics engine to a full. With excellent performances by its cast, it's able to greatly explain the story of Gordon and Alyx escaping City 17.With an excellent soundtrack composed by Kelly Bailey, the game becomes even more action packed, and the act of blasting zombies in an infected hospital with a shotgun becomes far more enjoyable, and the scene of fighting infected Combine soldiers in the underground becomes more threatening.The game also includes Developer commentary in the form of a commentary mode that allows the players to listen to the developers' thoughts on everything from map design to character and scene writing, and includes all variant of Valve Employee sharing their thoughts on the game.If I had to say I had any issues with the game, I'd have to say that it's fairly short, while Half-Life 2 is around 12-15 hours long, Episode One is around 5 hours long. That's not to say it's a bad game for that, though, as the story and game runs at a certain pace that allows for it to be enjoyed to the fullest; Replaying the game with the knowledge of how short it is doesn't damage or reduce the enjoyment of playing it, as Valve injects a great deal of fun into the game so there aren't many moments or time that is wasted, and every minute is used to its fullest.If you enjoyed Half-Life 2, and want more, I greatly suggest you buy the Half-Life Complete Steam bundle, preferably during a Steam Seasonal Sale. The bundle consists of this game and every other Valve-released Half-Life title, and is an essential for a fan of Half-Life.

												Half-Life 2: Episode One is science fiction first person shooter game developed by Valve Software on the Source Engine. It tells the continued story of physicist-gone-action-hero Gordon Freeman as he and action-hero-gone-love-interest Alyx Vance escape from the physically unstable City 17 before it blows up I think.In my review of Half-Life 2 I definitely wasn't very nice to the game. I said the game was unfocused and average, with interesting ideas and clever storytelling but drawn-out setpeices and a largely uninteresting plot if you remove all that glittery facial animation. Some of that, I think, is still justified but one thing I forgot to mention was how much I actually really like Half-Life 2.One thing the HL franchise enjoys doing is pulling the rug out from under the player and then throwing a bunch of enemies at them. That's pretty cool but it's also sort of troubling, considering that most of Half-Life 2 feels very aimless as if Gordon is just drunkenly stumbling between ambushes and set-peices. Episode 1 seemingly tries to fix that by making whatever the current goal is very obvious, either with some kind of environmental clue or with Alyx directly telling you what the objective is:Escape the towerGet to the train stationThe story is more grounded and because of that the gameplay can throw you into as many accidental circumstances and detours as it wants because you always end up back on track. I also appreciate how the stakes are a lot higher feeling in this game. It isn't just a vague intergalactic business proposition between Breen and some alien terrorist people, the actual city feels like it's about to blow up and if you keep getting interrupted by the combine than everybody involved will actually die. And it isn't just your life that's at stake here, you spend the entire game fighting alongside Alyx Vance, which sounds like a bad idea but this game manages a sidekick-idea very well.Anybody who played the first game remembers the third act where you command a squad consisting of that guy who sounds like everyone else and a girl who only occasionally dreams of cheese(?) but nobody WANTS to remember that part because not only is it sandwiched between the two best parts of the game but it also is un-doubtably the worst. The AI blocks the player at every turn and is super reliant on Gordon; they will not go anywhere unless you ask them too and they die as quickly as your enemies do so they may as well not be there--heck the game is more fun when they AREN'T there.The squad idea comes back in Episode 1 but not only are they more resistant, they seemingly abandon the whole "Targeting" thing--they seem to go wherever they want until you start to progress, and most importantly they stay out of the players way. All of this culminates into Alyx who not only follows the player from the very start but is INVULNERABLE to damage. This could make her too powerful but the devs fix that only giving her a pistol until about halfway through, and even before that she's a very good aim. Most of the opening is spent with the player under a variety of handicaps such as only having a gravity gun or not having a ton of ammo and the devs cleverly use Alyx as your second half, which not only ties their mostly plot-based comradery into the gameplay but also makes you feel like a real team by the end.Ultimately I think Episode 1 expands on HL2 and makes the game better. There's only one new enemy and a smaller arsenal than before but the gameplay is tightened and the story in more investing. I'll be the first to admit that my review of HL2 was a bit hyperbolic but I still recommended that game and I absolutely recommend Episode 1 as well

												The Half-Life 2 episodes were meant to be a foray into a new method of game development. Instead of spending several more years making Half-Life 3, Valve would release smaller iterations over shorter spans of time, which would also let them refine their work as they went. Coming out two years after HL2, Episode One was a relatively understated success, with improvements made in AI and the Source engine taking the technical spotlight.It's not nearly as long, dealing primarily with the aftermath of HL2's finale, but in the process avoids the drag that game sometimes suffered from. There's a decent variety here: the first third of the game only gives you one weapon to work with (albeit a powerful one), the second third is almost survival horror, and the final third is a roaring return to Combine-destroying action.You're partnered the entire time with Alyx Vance, who is thankfully more helpful and humorous here than annoying, and it's with that you realize that Valve also meant Episode One to be an exercise in character development that did more than just have you stand around for 5 minutes every time an NPC opens their mouth. The game is largely a success in that department too, and Valve's signature stealth brilliance in writing manages to make her not only cool, but human.If you're reading this, you probably already own it, but if you don't (or do and haven't played it for some reason) and were a fan of Half-Life 2, I'd say go for it. At the very least, it's a good bookend between its predecessor and its more outstanding sequel, Episode Two.

Though I wish that the crowbar was given to the player in the beginning of the game, instead of the half-way point where you no longer need it. I wish they just made the Flashlight not use your suit's battery so it could stay on indefinitely.I also really liked the Zombine enemy. They become a priority when dealing with hordes of Zombies and they can be actually quite helpful for you when they pull out a grenade and go kamikaze. If you're quick enough to get away they can  usually kill the horde of zombies for you. You can also shoot the grenade out of their hand or snatch it from them with the Grav Gun. She looks like a Mannequin at points and for a game whose main selling point is having Alyx fighting with you it seems like a big oversight, especially since the source engine has proven before that its quite good at making life-like animations. But it has some cool gunfights and helps to continue the story and transition into Episode two. Pay at most $4 and make sure you play the Minerva mod at some point to get your full money's worth.

 Half-Life 2: Episode 1 After the success of HL2, Valve made the design decision to release its sequels as episodic titles. This allowed them to capitalise more efficiently on rapidly improving graphical technology and dispense their content a lot faster. Released in 2006, Episode 1 is the direct continuation of HL2 which charts Gordon and Alyx’s treacherous escape from City 17. Technically, it attempts to improve and advance every aspect that its predecessor established.The gameplay of Episode 1 is based almost entirely around the concept of you working in partnership with your AI companion, Alyx. This mainly involves Alyx following your lead and helping you during combat, but there are also several innovative sections which reinforce the idea of teamwork. These include a dimly lit area where you need to use your flashlight to illuminate enemies for Alyx to shoot; and a section where you need to clear Alyx’s line of sight while she supports you from afar with a sniper rifle.She has been programmed to act as a support role, remaining reticent during puzzle sections and hanging back during ‘boss’ encounters. This feels like a well-balanced design choice as it allows the player the freedom to advance at their own pace and feel more of a sense of accomplishment at overcoming challenges.The AI has seen significant improvements, especially in path finding abilities. Alyx in particular has had a substantial upgrade, giving her new animations for crouching and synchronised kill moves for a lot of enemy types. Enemy AI has also seen developments as Combine soldiers can now crouch and take cover more effectively. They have also been given a rope repelling animation which always looks visually engaging. The only new enemy type introduced is the Combine zombie, or ‘zombine’. They are an entertaining addition that adds a new threat to the undead portions of the game.The puzzle sections are still relatively easy and should not take anyone too long to solve. Despite this, they are slightly more diverse than the simple physics based puzzles of the original game and still serve as an effective diversion from the combat scenes.Graphically, Episode 1 has seen some major upgrades. Valve has adapted their Source engine to include new developments in HDR (High Dynamic Range) lighting, which was originally showcased in their Lost Coast tech demo. This really helps to elevate the presentation to a high standard; for example the shader effects used around the Citadel core still manage to impress me today. There have also been further advancements in facial expression modelling which helps bring some more personality to the main characters.Overall, Episode 1 is a solid entry into the HL2 series. The main criticism that can be presented is its length; it is only five chapters long and can be comfortably completed in less than 10 hours. However, it is worth mentioning that there is also a developer commentary mode which provides some insightful observations if you are at all interested in the design process, or if you simply want to get a little more replay value.Personally I feel that Episode 1 provides the least story enhancement of the series, which can make it feel more inconsequential. However, from a technical stand point it does improve on almost every aspect in terms of gameplay and graphical experience, and is a well-polished presentation that serves as a good stepping stone into Episode 2.

												This is the epilogue to Half-Life 2, and it plays well.  You can see the Portal-like thinking in the design, especially at the beginning areas, which are a bit puzzle-based rather than combat heavy.  The difference is rather than using a portal device, you are using the gravity gun.  You don't even start with a crowbar.  Of course, this is just while the game prepares to return to form.  By the time it's over, you'll be back with crowbar in hand and a full array of weapons.  As well as the return of Gordon's followers.The game emphasizes the follower/NPC mechanics, as not only will Gordon have NPC followers helping him through parts of the game, but Alyx follows him for most of the game.  Rather than being a burden to be protected like too many escorts, however, Alyx is an active combatant, and more than holds her own.  You'll be glad she's there to draw fire and take down enemies at your side, and you'll notice the few times when she's pulled away to perform a background task and you have to go it solo.  It is a little abrupt, but it is worthy appendix to Half-Life 2's gameplay and storyline.

OverviewAfter the major success that Half-Life 2 was, many fans of the series were left wondering when the next installment of the Half-Life franchise would come out. It came as a shock when Valve announced that they would begin releasing episodic installments in their best selling franchise.Half-Life 2 Episode 1 is a continuation of Half-Life 2, picking up right where the last game ended instead of starting somewhere completely new. This may confuse many new players who haven't played the original hl2, but overall episode 1 is a nice bridge between Half-Life 2 and Half-Life 2 Episode 2.Pros Picks up right where hl2 left off, no time jumps Alyx's ai is very good for a game that is 9 years old, still works almost flawlessly. Game runs very well, very little lag and no crashes Game looks great, a few graphical updates from hl2 The soundtrack is very well done, the tracks flow very well with the gameplay.Cons The only setting in the game is City 17/the Citadel. Nothing we haven't already seen in hl2. The only new enemies are the Zombines and Stalkers.  The zombines are plentiful in numbers and are fun to mess around with, but the Stalkers don't even fight back and serve little to no purpose in the game. The game is quite short, even if it is supposed to be just an episode. You might finish it in an afternoon or two. Rating There is no denying that this is a good game. However compared to Half-Life 2 and Episode 2 this installment seems to be missing what made those 2 games masterpieces. You should definetely buy this game, and it is definetely worth 8 bucks. Just keep in mind that it doesn't bring a whole lot of new things to the table like the other ones did.8/10

												Half-Life 2: Episode One is a pretty good continuation of Half-Life 2. The game picks up the story from the point where Half-Life 2 ended: Gordon and Alyx are saved by the mysterious alien creatures (who are our allies here, altough we battled them - among other things - in the first game) both from the explosion and from the unpleasant guy in suit. What we get from here is an action packed escape, much like before, but this time with more zombies and almost completely set in the well known city environment. The finale may not seem as grandiose this time, but the final train ride is amazing.In addition to improved lighting, I noticed the particle effects (almost as good as in F.E.A.R.) looking better than the ones in the original game. It's visually striking how the light shines through the grains of dust.Gordon is accompanied by Alyx throughout the entire game and it is quite refreshing (the dialogues are pretty one-sided though, because Gordon still remains silent and fails to react to anything she says :)) to have her around, after the solitude of the original game. Alyx can still die if we don't pay attention, but this time she's more capable of defending herself.We have the same enemies (expect more zombies, antlions and striders) and weapons as usual (for me it wasn't an issue since I think the weapons are versatile enough), altough we can use the gravity gun more often - the environment is full of heavy, usable objects. As a matter of fact there is an achievement called 'The One Free Bullet' for which you can fire your gun only once throughout the whole game (the rocket launcher does not count as one, but the pistol, shotgun and machine guns do), that one time being crucial (you have to shoot a padlock to advance further). Attaining it may seem hindering, but it's quite fun and not as hard as it sounds.The main problem however arises from Half-Life 2: the story, or rather the lack of it. You still won't be able to find out anything about what's going on, moreover there are new mysteries as well, for example the huge, amorphous creature we meet at the beginning (seemingly using some sort of psionic attacks). For someone who values storyline above almost anything else in a single player game, this counts as quite a big mistake.After all the game is still great, but Valve should have given at least a bit more answers instead of extending the core Half-Life 2 getaway gameplay with a few more hours. Talking about hours, the game is also pretty short and can be finished in about 6 hours (took me less than 13 hours with all achievements attained). I don't think that it's such a big problem however, since it wasn't priced as a full game at it's release. It feels a bit like a link between the original Half-Life 2 and Episode 2, but I'm not saying it should be given a miss. On the contrary, you should definitely play it as it's still a great game and has some memorable moments (make sure to listen to Dr. Kleiner's speech on the menu or ingame via the city screens :))PROS+ improved lighting and particle effects+ having Alyx as a sidekick is fun+ combat is still great, fighting striders is thrilling+ some very creative achievementsCONS- story is still functional, no explanations- setting is motonous- a bit too shortRATING7.5/10

												Half-Life 2: Episode OneA Combine Zombie. That's, that's like a... ah... a Zombine! Right? After Half-Life 2 was released in 2004, Valve decide to release their next Half-Life instalments in episodic sequences. This meant they could release these titles more frequently and thus fans would not have to wait as long between each instalment.***Warning, contains spoilers to previous games in the Half-Life series***The game picks up right where it left of, with the reactor in the Citadel exploding and Gordon being put into ‘stasis’ once again by the G-man. In the opening sequence a group of Vortigaunts enter the G-man’s ‘realm’ and rescue Gordon, bringing him back to city 17. After Dog and Alyx recover Gordon from beneath some rubble, they get in contact with Dr. Kliner and Eli Vance. Gordon and Alyx are informed that the Citadel core is at risk of exploding, levelling the whole city, and that they must renter the Citadel and slow the core's progression toward meltdown if they want to escape with their lives. The storyline in this game is not overly complicated as it is a very short game, taking roughly 5 hours to complete. The majority of the game is spent with Alyx, fighting off stalkers with the supercharged Gravity Gun and walking your way through abandon carparks and hospitals infested with Antlions, Headcrab Zombies and Combine Soldiers.The gameplay, as in Half-Life 2, is extraordinary. This game not only has the great puzzles and bloody shootouts like in previous games, but to keep them interesting, Valve has introduced some new features such as the Zombine, which is a Combine Soldier turned into a Zombie by Head Crabs. They have the ability to throw a grenade at you and run much faster than the normal Headcrab Zombies. Although they failed to introduce a new weapon, you can now pick up flares which are scattered throughout the game and throw them at enemies, lighting them on fire. Taking out stalkers in the citadel, escorting citizens to a train, fighting a Combine Gunship on the roof of a hospital and battling a Strider at a train station, are all highlights of the awesome gameplay in this game.The soundtracks, once again, significantly add to the gameplay. Although I can’t say there were any standouts, each one was perfectly fitted to its scene. ‘Disrupted Original’ is played during the large Zombie attack in the chapter lowlife and really adds to the tension of the scene. ‘Combine Advisory’ is played when you enter the shaft full of advisor pods, the eerie music coupled with the futuristic design of the citadel gives the whole sequence a serial and scary feeling.Level design in Half-Life has always been a strong suit of the franchise. Even though the games are linier, they can feel at times, very open world. In ‘Half-Life Episode One’ this feeling isn’t as strong as it is a short game set entirely in City 17. However each new sequence, from the citadel, to the streets, to the train station, have an incredible design. The Attic, were you fight a Gunship, can be completely destroyed giving you a limited time to hide between each shot form your rocket launcher. In the chapter Lowlife, the carpark in which you must wait for an elevator to take you to the surface is extremely dark with the only source of light being your HEV suit torch (which runs out quickly) flares (which are quite scarce) and burning crates and Head Crab Zombies if you manage to set them alight. This makes the chapter much more intense as you are constantly bombarded with waves of Head Crab Zombies which are difficult to see.This game, although not nearly as good as Half-Life 2, is still amazing. The gameplay is incredibly enjoyable however the final battle with the Strider was a bit lacking and was a relatively easy encounter for Gordon considering what he went through in previous Half-Life games. The soundtracks work well with this gameplay adding to the overall atmosphere of the scene. Level design was well thought out and even for a short, linier game, set in a cramped city, it still felt very expansive. I would say that the strongest aspect of this game is probably the story as it managed to answer a lot of unresolved questions from the end of Half-Life 2 in a very short time span, and was able to set up an even better plot for future instalments in the Half-Life series.9/10

												Half-Life 2: Episode One is the first story-driven expansion for the original Half-Life 2 by Valve. Taking play mere minutes after the end of the first game's campaign, it follows the effort of both Gordon and Alyx as they try to escape City 17, where the collapse of the Combine Citadel is about to set off a huge explosion.As far as gameplay goes, nothing really changes from the main game, aside for new situations you have to face with the instruments you are given (one sequence, for instance, requires you to shine your flashlight on enemies to help Alyx killing them while you don't have weapons to speak of). Alyx will accompany you for the whole episode and fight alongside you.As a downside, this time around Gordon isn't as effective as in the original Half-Life 2: you spend the first half of the game armed with your gravity gun only and generally you unlock other weapons at a slow pace. While this forces you to relay on the environment and your creativity more, it can get annoying during particularly hard sequences.Half-Life 2: Episode One is roughly three or four hours long and takes places in environments you already got yourself familiar with, but still it expands nicely on the original story and keeps the gameplay fresh enough

												Half Life 2: Episode One while a very short game it is still a great 'short game' to be played. If you want more juicy details check out my Half Life 2 review for more information. Anywho. Let us get the elephant out of the room. This particular episode tries a little bit too hard at what it wants to be. Is this still an action adventure game? Is it a science-fiction horror FPS? The reason why I say this is because unlike in Half Life 2 where the sections are spread out. The "chapters" jump from one genre to the next with really no breather for the player. And I guess you can say it's because of the "intense" circumstances of the story. But still, Episode One could've used more chapters to spread things out rather than just cramming it all in.The story obviously takes places just hours after the events of Half Life 2. The overall goal is to get out of City 17. That's basically it. You get some "new" 'plot questions' in this particular game. But these 'plot questions' won't be explained until Episode 2. And even then, the new plot questions you encountered in this game and in the next episode won't be REALLY answered until (Half Life 3) <- Lol. I recommend this game. But! And this might be a hard pill to swallow. But, I think Episode One and Two should've just been in the ACTUAL Half Life 2 game rather than spacing the game out. It might've been because of budget or giving players a breather. If that's the case then they should've made Ep 1 and Ep 2 into purchasable expansions rather than actual 'full games'. I recommend buying the Orange Box rather than the games seperately btw.

The game is absolutely worth playing through and should not be overlooked in any case. if you were hoping that Episode One would shed more light on Half-Life 2's cryptic storyline, keep on dreaming. Taking a cue from "Lost," Episode One dances around key plot mysteries while giving very little in the way of new information.

												My review for Half-Life 2 can be seen here:http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198056186683/recommended/220It's good, damn good but it's not as good as Half-Life 2 or Episode 2. This has got some damn good atmosphere and combat sequnces and while short stands tall as an excellent adventure amongst FPS titles and expansions. That said it really is the middle child of the Half-Life 2 family. From replaying I've come to think it's real weaknesses come from it's exposition heavy,slow start and opening Citadel chapters. Especially when  all combined. It has you teamed up with Alyx for the entire episode and thankfully she is well written, helpful and interesting and a damn impressive showcase of AI unlike a certain Sheva. At the same time though you'll often be locked into what I call little "cutscene" rooms. YES you can move around freely as control is never taken away from the player in the Half-Life games but while these "cutscenes" as well written and interesting as they are are also unskipable and if it's not your first time playing all you can do is leap around like a fussy cat and make people look like an idiot as you attempt to jump on their head or find something to throw. The tunnels, and ESPECIALLY the remains of City 17 are when it's best. The Citadel isn't bad, FAR FROM IT, but it wasn't my favorite part on repeat playthroughs and it keeps me from speedily progressing to my favorite parts faster if I don't skip massive chunks of the gamet via chapter select that is.Episode 1 does a lot of things scripting and scenario wise that I've never seen all together in one single FPS game before especially in terms of it's design and layout but then it will repeat some of these good parts a little too much and as a cherry on top will have a character openly say "oh god no", "not again" and "here we go again" winkingly as you do a reocurring scripted sequence involving Combine, explosives and doors. Having a character remark at how over used a gimmick in game is and then DOING the gimmick anyway does not then excuse or fix the gimmick. It sticks out like a sore thumb as this sort of thing is uncommon in the game prior. It's like when Duke in Duke Nukem Forever sighed in disgust at a literal pipe puzzle and said "I hate Valve puzzles." and then proceeding to do it anyway. (And no I am not saying anything in this game is as bad as any part of the Duke Nukem Forever.)It's short (real short) but sweet and unless you don't wan't to wait forever for a conclusion after you play Episode 2 I highly reccomend you play Episode 1. It's forced, ending in disappointment. I'd still recommend to play it, because it is necessary to play the games in sequence and the entry Half-Life 2: Episode Two is in my opinion worth it after making it through this average disappointment. Otherwise it might be difficult to follow and therefore less enjoyable so therefore, I wouldn't advise you to skip this. Due to its age, and because of  the short length, I recommend buying this at a price that matches or exceeds a seventy-five percent markdown (it very regularly goes on sale at low prices, they may as well offer the entire Half-Life franchise for free), but even better just buy the Orange Box because it comes with all of the Half-Life games and Portal (which is in the same universe) and after considering the price, it is the better value.I also recommend Garry's Mod if you're buying ancient source engine games because it provides more assets for Garry's Mod, it has tons of different game modes that you can enjoy online through public servers, such as roleplaying, cinema, and a Quake 3 recreation. I bet some of you are rolling your eyes and going, "Well, DUH, that's why it's called Half-Life 2: Episode ONE!"  Well, it certainly feels as if I played the game already...which I did...and Episode One is merely the equivalent of a DLC add-on...which, given the title, it certainly is. An example would be how in the original game, the gravity gun got upgraded at the end, whereas in Episode One, it gets upgraded at the very beginning...and then it's suddenly downgraded to its usual status during the rest of the game.  I was hoping I would be able to lift and throw enemy bosses with the thing had the upgrade stayed on, but the game said no, which is still a very major flaw with this game.  Getting through Episode One literally got me through half the time it took to get through the orignal game, and that's including getting almost every Achievement. 												Valve made a gigantic mistake with their episodic release concept. It tried to deliver content faster and it failed immensely, giving chunks that just weren't enough to please fans at the time. The cliffhanger ending didn't help either, a cheap way to end any game. Then if that wasn't enough, they stuck Alyx at the side of the player throughout the game. She becomes more of a nuisance than a welcome partner, mainly with her intimate remarks towards the player. Her nonstop presence is in stark contrast to previous titles, where the player's quest was mostly a lonely ride with only short periods where characters followed. This sense of isolation really improved the previous titles, and here I feel it was a bad design choice to stick Alyx to the player for all of the ride. I think the main reason why Alyx doesn't work, is because she ends up trying to be romantic with the player and not Gordon, as Gordon doesn't talk or have any personality, he's just a suit for the player to wear. This ends up being incredibly awkward.All in all the episodic content idea was bad, even Valve knows this. It delivered an underwhelming chunk of a game that didn't provide enough, and it was also marred by the continous presence of a character whose remarks towards the player were more cringe inducing than story-building.

												This review contains spoilers regarding Half-Life 2.Riding on the high octane ending of Half-Life 2 and acting as a direct continuation, Half-Life 2: Episode One manages to be a safe, if not fulfilling, addition to the Half-Life series.Sticking with the known working formula, in Half-Life 2: Episode One you resume control of Gordon Freeman. Throwing the ending of that game to one side, Gordon finds himself back in City 17 with Alyx and a Citadel on the verge of leveling the entire city. Throughout this episode you venture back into the Citadel to contain the core and then proceed to try and escape City 17 before its destruction.The issue with this game is it brings very little new to the table. The environments are all rehashes of what was seen in HL2 - the Citadel, the streets and buildings of City 17. The only original feeling portion of the game is where you have to fight through a hospital, constantly being assaulted by Combine and Zombies, with an assault ship opening fire through any window you pass by. Amongst the zombie horde is a new creature: the Zombine. This headcrabbed Combine soldier is stronger and faster than the other zombies, possessing the ability to pull grenades out in a kamikaze run. It spices up the variety little, but only a little, for the most aprt they still act like everything else you've encountered so far. The sections with the Citadel are interesting; now a degenerating and highly unstable building that the Combine are fleeing, but ultimately it's not too indifferent from the final stages of HL2.The final, and largest, criticism is the length. This game can be completed in roughly five hours. For a game that offers little advancement in plot, instead focusing mainly on combat, there's not a lot here to make it an essential play. Don't get me wrong, it's worth playing if not just to have an excuse to dip back into the HL2 world, but this game struggles to have any sort of re-playability value when HL2 does everything this game does - only better.
